sample.head: 3 OF MASTER HOBSON AND IOHN TAWNYCOTE.
sample.nonSpeech: After Hobson being a haberdasher of small wares (as I sayd before) & his shoppe on a time full of customers, his negligent Prentises, carelessly creditted a kentish pedler with ten pounds of commodities, neither knowing his name nor his dwelling place, which ouersight, when maister Hobson vnderstood, and noting the simplicity SOURCE TEXT: smplicity of his seruantes, and their forgetfulnes, demanded what apparrell the pedler had on?
sample.dialogue: mary Sir
he had on a Taunycote, Then
put downe Iohn tauny cote
sample.nonSpeech: and so was the pedler, by the name of Iohn tauny cote , entred to the booke, about a month after the same pedler, came againe to London to buy ware, and comming to maister Hobson in a russet cote willed him to turne ouer his booke for ten poundes that one Iohn Rowlands owed him.
sample.dialogue: Ten pounds,
that Iohn Rowlands oweth me, I remember no such man, bones of God knaue, thou owest mee none, but I doe
sample.nonSpeech: saith the pedler: where vpon the booke was serched, but no Iohn Rowlands was to be found,
sample.dialogue: I thinke thou art mad
for thou owest me nothing, but I doe
and will pay it.
sample.nonSpeech:
Being in this
strife a long time one of his seruants said, that hee had found in the booke such a debte by one Iohn tawny cote
sample.dialogue: that is my selfe
I was then Iohn tawny cote , though I am now Iohn Russet cote ,
sample.nonSpeech: so paid hee the ten pounds by the same name to Maister Hobson , and receiued twenty more vpon his owne word and name of Iohn Rowland , the which twenty pound, hee shortly after paid for suertyshippe and so by this his ouer kind heart, paying other mens debtes, hee grew so poore, and into such necessity, that he was forced to maintaine his liuing by hedging and ditching and other such like country labours, within a while after this, Maister Hobson comming into kent, to seeke vp some desperate debts, came to Dartford , where finding this poore man ditching for a groat a day, in pitty of him said
sample.dialogue: how now Iohn tawny cote , bones a God man, thou canst neuer pay me with this poore labour, come home knaue, come home I will trust thee with twenty pound more, follow thy old trade of pedling again & one day thou maiest pay me all.

sample.head: 5. HOW MAISTER HOBSON CHAUK'D HIS PRENTISSES THE WAY TO THE CHURCH.
sample.nonSpeech: Euermore when Maister Hobson had any buisines abroad, his prentises wold ether bee at the tauerne, filling there heads with wine, or at the dagger in cheapeside cramming their bellies with minced pyes, but aboue al other times, it was their common costome (as London prentises vse) to follow their maisters vpon sundays to the Church dore) and then to leaue them and hie vnto the tauerne, which Maister Hobson on a time, perceuing one of his men so to doe, demanded at his comming home, what the Preachers text was:
sample.dialogue: Sir
I was not at the beginning, what was in the midle
Sir
then was I a sleepe:
what was then the conclusion?
I was come sir away before the end:
sample.nonSpeech: by which meanes he knew well he was not there, but rather in some tipling house offending Gods maiesty and the lawes of the land.

sample.head: 12 HOW MAISTER HOBSON GOT A PATTENT FOR THE SALE OF HIS MATCHES.
sample.dialogue:
HOBSON WAS RECEIVED BY QUEEN ELIZABETH WHEN HE SOUGHT A PATENT FOR SELLING MATCHES.
my friend
bee content for thou shalt not haue thy pattent sealed, nor will I giue thee thy request,
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson hearing the Queenes denial said,
sample.dialogue: I most hartely thanke your maiesty, both I and all mine, are bound to thanke and pray for your highnes:
sample.nonSpeech: and so making lowe obeysance, went his way: at these his words SOURCE TEXT: wo ds , the Queene much maruailed, and when he had gone a litle from her, she caused him to be sent for backe againe, whome when he was returned, the Queene asked, if he did well vnderstand what answer her grace did giue him,
sample.dialogue: yes truely
what said I
marry your grace bad me be content for I should not haue my desire, nor my pattent sealed, why did you SOURCE TEXT: your then
giue me such great thanks? because

your grace gaue mee so soone an answere without either longer sute, or losse of time, the which would haue bene to my very much harme and great hinderance, for I haue at home a mighty charge of household, to which I am bound in duety to looke diligently, and to maintaine carefully.
sample.nonSpeech:
The Queene marking well the wisdom, and discreet answer of Maister Hobson ,
and now conceauing a new fauour towards him, sayd,
sample.dialogue: now shall you giue me twice thanks, for you shall haue your pattent sealed, and your desiers performed that you sue for.

sample.head: MASTER HOBSONS IEST OF RINGING OF BELLS VPON THE QUEENES DAY.

dialogue.comment: HOBSON, WHO WAS CHURCHWARDEN, WAS ASKED WHY HE WAS NOT RINGING THE BELLS ON THE QUEEN'S ANNIVERSARY: HOBSON SAID THAT THEY HAD NO BELLS IN THE STEEPLE.

sample.dialogue: may you very wel sel a way your steeple, why so
because
it standet emty and vacant
sample.nonSpeech: to whom maister Hobson replyed againe,
sample.dialogue: we may better sell awaye our pulpet, for these twelue mounths was there neuer a sermon in the same and it rather stands empty and vacant
sample.nonSpeech: after this the parson of the church preached euery Sonday following.

sample.head: OF A BEGERS ANSWEAR TO MAISTER HOBSON.
sample.nonSpeech: Poore begger man, that was foule, blacke, and loathsome to behould, came on a time to Maister Hobson as he walked in Moore feelds, and asked something of him for an almes, to whom Maister Hobson said,
sample.dialogue: I prethee good fellow get thee from me, for thou lookst as thou camst lately out of hell,
sample.nonSpeech: the poore begger man perceuing, hee would giue him nothing, answered forsooth.
sample.dialogue: Sir, you say true, for I came lately out of Hell indeed, why didst not thou tarry there still
nay Sir
there is no Roome for such begerr men as I am, for all is kept for such gentlemen Cittizens as you be:
sample.nonSpeech: this wity answere caused Maister Hobson to giue the poore man a teaster.

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON CAUSED HIS MAN TO SET VP A SIGNE.
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson hauing one of his Prentices new come out of his time and being made a free man of London, desired to set vp for himself, so taking a house not far from Saint Laurence lane, furnished it with store of ware, & set the signe of the Mayden head: hard by was a very rich man of the same trade, had the same signe, and reported in euery place where he came, that y=e= yong man had set vp y=e= same signe that he had, onely to get a way his customers, & dayly vexed the yong man therewithall, who being greued in mind, made it knowne to Maister Hobson his late maister who comming to the rich man said,
sample.dialogue: I maruell Sir
why you wrong my man so much as to say he seketh to get away your customers, mary so he doth
for he hath set vp a signe called the maiden head as mine is, that is not so
for his is the widdoes head, and no mayden head, therefore you do him great wrong:
sample.nonSpeech: the rich man hereupon seing himselfe requited with mocks, rested satisfied, and neuer after that enuied Maister Hobsons man, but let him liue quietly.

sample.head: OF MAISTER HOBSONS IEST OF A LOUSE AND A FLEA.

dialogue.comment: HOBSON WAS GOING TO THE MAYOR'S: HIS APPRENTICE SPOTTED A LOUSE ON HIS CLOTHES AND WIPED IT AWAY.

sample.nonSpeech: maister Hobson espying him to doe some thing in secret, asked what it was? the fellow being ashamed, was loath to tell him, but being importuned by his maister said it was a louse:
sample.dialogue: oh
this is good lucke: for it sheweth me to be a man, for this kind of vermine chiefly breedeth on mankind,
sample.nonSpeech: and there-vpon gaue fiue shillings to his man for his labour: another of his Prentises being a pickthanke-knaue and hauing hard that his fellow had fiue shilings giuen him for taking a louse from of his maister (hauing his gowne likewise on) and made as though he tooke a flea from the same, & conuayed it priuily away, but when maister Hobson constrayned him to tell what it was, with much dissembling shamefastnes he said it was a flea: Maister Hobson perceuing his disimulation said to him,
sample.dialogue: what dost thou make mee a dogge? for fleas be most commonly bread vpon dogs:
sample.nonSpeech:
and so the fiue shillinges he lookd for
he had giuen fiueteene stripes:
sample.dialogue: for
there is great difference betweene one that doth a thing with a good mind, and him that doth a thing by disimulation

sample.head: HOW ONE OF MAISTER HOBSONS MEN QUITED HIM WITH A MERRY IEST.
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson had a seruant that hee had long before made a freeman and was still at maister Hobsons commaundment & did him much good seruice, wherfore vpon a time hee came vnto his maister and said,
sample.dialogue: Sir, I haue done your seruice SOURCE TEXT: seruce long time iust and truly, wherefore I pray you bestowe some thing vpon mee to begin the world with all, fellow,

thou sayst true, & hereon haue I thought many times to doe a good turne, now will I tell thee what thou shalt doe, I must shortly ride to Bristowe faire, and if thou wilt beare my charges thether, I will giue thee such a thing, as shall be worth to thee a hundred pounds: I am content
sample.nonSpeech: (quoth the fellowe) so all the way as hee Road, his man bore his charges, & paid for all things dewly, till they came to their last lodging and there after supper he came to his maister & said:
sample.dialogue:
Sir, I haue borne your charges as you commanded me, now I pray you let me know what the thing is that will be worth to me a hundred
pounds? did I promise thee such a thing
you did
shew it me in wrighting
I haue none
then thou art like to haue nothing

and learne this of me, when so euer thou makest a bargaine with any man, looke that thou take a wrighting for thy security, and be wel aduised how thou giuest thy bond to any man, this thing hath benefitted me in my time a hundred pounds, and so may it likewise do thee: THE APPRENTICE PAID ALL THE CHARGES BY PAWNING HOBSON'S CLOAK: IT STARTED TO RAIN.
sample.nonSpeech: so they tooke shellter vnder a tree, till he ouer tooke them, when he was come, maister Hobson most angerly, sayd:
sample.dialogue: thou knaue why comst not thou away with my cloke: Sir and please you

SOURCE TEXT: fellow( I haue layd it to pawne for your charges all the
way: why knaue
didest not thou promisse to beare my charges to Bristowe . did I
yes
that thou didest, shew me a wrighting then therefore
sample.nonSpeech: (said the fellow) wherevnto Maister Hobson (seeing him selfe so cunningly ouerreached) answered but litle.

sample.head: OF MAISTER HOBSONS RIDING TO STURBRIGE FAIRE.
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson on a time in company of one of his neighbors roade from London towards Sturbrige faire, so the first night of there iorny they lodged at Ware in an Inne where great store of Company was, and in the morning when euery man made him ready to ride, and some were on horsbacke setting forward, the Cittizen his neighbour found him sitting at the Inne gate booted and spurd in a browne studdy, to whome hee saide,
sample.dialogue: for shame Maister Hobson why sitte you heare, why doe you not make your selfe redy to horse backe, that we may set forward with company?
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson replyed in this manner,
sample.dialogue: I tarry
for a good cause: for what cause
mary

here be so many horses, that I cannot tell which
is mine owne, and I know well, when euery man is ridden and gone the horse that remaneth behind, must needs be mine.

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON FOUND A FARMERS PURSE.

dialogue.comment: A FARMER LOST A PURSE WITH FORTY POUNDS: HE PROMISED TO GIVE FIVE POUNDS TO THE PERSON WHO WOULD FIND IT. HOBSON FOUND THE PURSE BUT THE FARMER NOW CLAIMED THAT IT CONTAINED FORTY-FIVE POUNDS AND THAT HOBSON HAD ALREADY TAKEN FIVE POUNDS. THE CASE WAS BROUGHT BEFORE A JUSTICE OF PEACE, FLEETWOOD, WHO ASKED TO SEE THE PURSE.

sample.nonSpeech:
but when Maister Fleetewood , vnderstood by the bayleife, that the proclamation was made for a purse of
fiue and forty pound, he demanded where it was
sample.dialogue: here
sample.nonSpeech: quoth the baylie, and gaue it him,
sample.dialogue: is it iust forty pound
yes truly
here maister Hobson ,
take you this mony for it is your owne, and if you chance to find a purse of fiue and forty pound bring it to this honest farmer, that is mine
for I lost iust forty pound, you speake to late
sample.nonSpeech: (quoth maister Fleetewood ) thus the farmer lost the mony, and maister Hobson had it according to iustice.

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON WAS A IUDGE BETWIXT TWO WOMEN.
sample.dialogue:
TWO WOMEN COMPETE ABOUT WHO WAS THE YOUNGER OF THEM, AND ELECTED HOBSON AS JUDGE IN THE MATTER: ONE GAVE HIM A PIDGEON-PIE, THE OTHER A GREYHOUND. HOBSON DECLARED THAT SHE WHO GAVE HIM THE DOG WAS THE YOUNGER. THE OTHER WOMAN ASKED HOBSON WHY.
Sir, I gaue you a pidgion pie, and you promised the verdit should goe on my side.
of a truth good woman, there came a grayhound into my house, and eate vp the pidgion pye, and so by that meanes I quite forgot thee.

sample.head: OF THE PRIDE OF MAISTER HOBSONS WIFE.
sample.nonSpeech:
Maister Hobsons wife carrying something a stately mind, and delighting in braue apprell, vpon a time walking abroad with other women her neighbours, they espied a payre of
silke stockins vpon her legges and desiring the like, neuer let their husbands to liue in quiet after, til they had silke stockins of the same fashion: so within a weeke or two following, their husbandes came complayning to maister Hobson and said,
sample.dialogue: Sir,

the sufferance of your wiues pride, hath spoyled all ours, for since she hath worne silke stockings, our wiues haue growne so importunate, that they must needs haue the like, and you are the cheifest cause in suffering her to weare the same: Oh my good neighbours,
I haue great cause in doing so and it bringes me much quietnes, as how
mary thus (neighboures) for seeing I cannot please her aboue the knee, I most needs please her belowe the knee, and the only thing to please a woman is to let her haue her will.

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON FOUND OUT THE PYE STEALER.

dialogue.comment: A SERVANT STOLE A PIE. HOBSON GAVE ALL HIS SERVANTS PLENTY TO DRINK, AND WHEN THEY WERE ALL SAT AT THE TABLE HOBSON SPOKE AS FOLLOWS.

sample.dialogue: why sit you not downe fellowes, we be set allredy
nay
he that stole the pye is not set yet, yes that I doe
sample.nonSpeech: (quoth he that stole it) SOURCE TEXT: it( by which meanes he knew what was become of the pye, for the poore fellow being drunke could not keepe his owne secretts.

sample.head: OF MAISTER HOBSON AND A DOCTOR OF PHISICKE.
sample.nonSpeech: Vpon a time when Maister Hobson lay sicke, and in very great payne, there came vnto him a Doctor of Phisicke, that tould him he could not escape but must needs die of that sicknes, Maister Hobson a while after, not by the Doctors helpe, but by the will of God, recouered, and was whole of his disease, yet was he very lowe, and bare brought, and as he walked forth on a day, he met the said Doctor which doubting whether it ware the sicke man or no, sayd
sample.dialogue:
are SOURCE TEXT: (are not you Sir the man called
maister Hobson ? yes trewly
are you aliue or dead
I am dead
what doe you here then
I am here
because I haue experience in many earthly things and God hath sent me to the world againe, with a commandement to take vp all Phisitions that I can get and send them thether to him,
sample.nonSpeech: which saying made Maister Doctor as pale as ashes for feare, Maister Hobson seing this sayd vnto him,
sample.dialogue: feare not Maister Doctor though I said all phisitions, for you are none, and there is no man that hath witte will take you for one: therfore you are not in my charge: farewell

sample.head: OF MA. HOBSONS SORE EYES & HIS ANSWER TO PHISITIONS
sample.nonSpeech: Vpon a time, when master Hobso~ had sore eyes, there came a certaine Phisition to him, thinking to haue some recompence for his councell, warning him that he should in any case forbeare drinking, or ells by the same loose his eyes, to whom Master Hobson sayde,
sample.dialogue:
it is much more
pleasure for me to loose my eyes with drinking then to keepe them for worms to eate them out:
sample.nonSpeech: another time a phisition came to maister Hobson and said,
sample.dialogue: Sir you looke well, and greeue at nothing, and haue a healthfull countenance, true
for I haue not to doe with any Phisitions, nor with Phisicke:
Sir
you haue no cause to blame the phisition, for his Phisicke neuer did you hurt, thou saist true
for if I had proued Phisicke, I had not beene now heare aliue:
sample.nonSpeech: another Phisition, came to him on a time and said,
sample.dialogue: Sir you be a very ould man, (very trew
for thou wert neuer my Phisition,
sample.nonSpeech: such maner of checkes and floutes would he stil giue to them that spoke to him of Phisicke, for in all his life hee neuer tooke any.

sample.head: OF MASTER HOBSONS IEST OF THE SIGNE OF SAINT CHRISTOPHER.
sample.nonSpeech: Maister Hobson , and another of his neighbours on a time walking to Southwarke faire, by chance drunke in a house, which had the signe of Sa. Christopher , of the which signe the good man of the house gaue this commendation,
sample.dialogue: Saint Christopher

SOURCE TEXT: (quoth he when hee liued vpon the
earth bore the greatest burden that euer was, which was this, he bore Christ ouer a riuer, nay there was one
that bore a greater burden, who was that
mary
the asse that bore both him and his mother:
sample.nonSpeech: so was the Inne-keeper called asse by craft. After this talking merely together, the a forsaid Inne keeper being a litle whitled with drinke & his head so giddy that he fell into the fire, people standing by ran sodainely and tooke him vp,
sample.dialogue: oh let him alone
a man may doe what he will in his owne house, and lie where so euer he listeth,
sample.nonSpeech: the man hauing little hurt, with this fight grew immediately sober,

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON BID AN ALDERMAN TO DINER.

dialogue.comment: HOBSON ASKED A VERY TALKATIVE SERVANT TO INVITE AN ALDERMAN TO DINNER: HOBSON HAD URGED HIS SERVANT NOT TO TALK SO MUCH.

sample.nonSpeech: so vpon the day when diner time came, all the guestes stayd for the said Alldermans comming till two of the clocke, and so at last maister Hobson , sayd vnto his seruant:
sample.dialogue: didst thou bid maister Alderman to diner? yes truly
why cometh he not then?
mary
he said hee could not: why touldst thou not me so
because
you did not aske me? here-vpon
sample.nonSpeech: (though long first) they went all to diner, and being mery together drinking of wine there came in a certaine ruffen and stole one of the fairest silluer cupps a way the which the fellow seing, said neuer a word but let him goe, which when maister Hobson missed, he demanded of his seruant where it was
sample.dialogue: Sir
a theefe came in and stole it a way: why didst not thou stay him
mary sir,
because he asked no question of me,
sample.nonSpeech: after this, maister Hobson noting the simplenes of his seruant let him haue his toung at free liberty.

sample.head: HOW MAISTER HOBSON SAID HE WAS NOT AT HOME.

dialogue.comment: HOBSON VISITED FLEETWOOD BUT FLEETWOOD DID NOT WISH TO SEE HIM AND TOLD ONE OF HIS MEN TO SAY THAT HE WAS NOT AT HOME: HOBSON UNDERSTOOD THIS AND FLEETWOOD THEN CAME TO HOBSON.

sample.nonSpeech: & knocking at the dore, asked if he were within? maister Hobson hearing, and knowing how he was denyed maister Fleete-woods speach before time, speake himselfe aloud, and said, hee was not at home, Then sayd maister Fleete-wood ,
sample.dialogue: what master Hobson , thinke you that I knowe not your voyce,
sample.nonSpeech: where-vnto maister Hobson answered and sayd,
sample.dialogue: now maister Fleete-wood , am I quit with you: for when I came to speake with you, I beleeued your man that said, you were not at home, and now you will not beleeue mine owne selfe,
sample.nonSpeech:
and this was the mery conference betwixt these two merry gentlemen,
FINIS .
